papaya_details.description: Papaya is a tropical fruit known for its sweet, orange flesh and black seeds encased in a green or yellow skin. It belongs to the Caricaceae family and is native to the tropical regions of the Americas.
papaya_details.nutritional value: Papaya is rich in vitamin C, vitamin A, fiber, and antioxidants such as beta-carotene and lycopene. It supports digestive health, boosts immune function, and may reduce the risk of chronic diseases.
papaya_details.uses: Fresh consumption, Juicing, Smoothies, Salads, Desserts, Sauces
papaya_details.varieties: Solo, Maradol, Sunrise, Hawaiian, Red Lady
papaya_details.ripening: Papayas continue to ripen after being harvested, so they are typically harvested when they reach maturity and allowed to ripen at room temperature.
papaya_details.ripeness indicator: A ripe papaya will have a slightly soft texture when gently pressed, a sweet aroma, and skin that yields to pressure.
papaya_details.harvest season: Papayas can be harvested year-round in tropical climates. However, they have peak seasons depending on the variety and location.

prerequisites.soil: Papayas prefer well-drained, sandy or loamy soil with good fertility and a slightly acidic to neutral pH (around 6.0 to 7.0).
prerequisites.climate: Papayas thrive in tropical to subtropical climates with warm temperatures (around 75°F to 90°F or 24°C to 32°C) and high humidity.
prerequisites.sunlight: Papayas require full sunlight for optimal growth and fruit development.
prerequisites.water: Regular watering, especially during periods of drought or dry weather, to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged.
prerequisites.space: Plant papaya trees at least 8 to 10 feet apart to allow for proper air circulation and sunlight penetration.
